intro: Hesperochiron pumilus var. ciliatus, commonly known as the hairy false nettle, is a low-growing herbaceous plant characterized by its soft, hairy leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers. It belongs to the family Urticaceae, which includes stinging nettles, and shares some morphological features with its relatives. The plant typically thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its leaves are often arranged in opposite pairs and have a distinctive ciliated edge, contributing to its scientific name. The flowers are usually greenish-white and clustered in dense inflorescences, making it a subtle yet ecologically important species in its habitat.
